docs.lead_paragraph: The sale of fake or diluted drugs has reached disturbing proportions in the developing world, according to an article in The British Medical Journal. A sampling of drugs sold by vendors in Cambodia found that 60 percent of the antimalaria pills sampled were either fake or cheaper, less effective compounds than were claimed.
docs.abstract: Survey of drug samples sold by vendors in South East Asian and African contries, published in British Medical Journal, finds large percentages of antimalaria pills were either fake or diluted (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like most pediatricians, Dr. Eric Poon usually obtains a child's weight and height during an examination and records them on a set of standardized growth charts. This allows him to compare the child's growth to that of thousands of other children and to determine whether it is adequate, inadequate or, in these times of rampant obesity, too adequate.

headline.main: New Growth Charts Dispel the Myth That One Size Fits All

docs.abstract: Article on new standardized growth charts developed from data collected during several recent annual national health and nutrition surveys based on millions of children that better reflect US racial and ethnic diversity and include formula and breast-fed babies; team of nutritionists, pediatricians and statisticians, reporting in January issue of Pediatrics, reports striking improvement in accuracy of charts; graphs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Like most pediatricians, Dr. Eric Poon usually obtains a child's weight and height during an examination and records them on a set of standardized growth charts.     This allows him to compare the child's growth to that of thousands of other children...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''My name is Hubert, and I'm a sugar addict.'' Yes, some groups aim at overeating or food addiction in general, but there are no local chapters of, say, ''Chocoholics Anonymous'' where I could stand and say that. Maybe there should be.

headline.main: Sweet Taste Of Beating Sugar Habit

docs.abstract: Hubert B Herring Cases column describes how he overcame addiction to sweets (M)
docs.snippet: ''My name is Hubert, and I'm a sugar addict.''    Yes, some groups aim at overeating or food addiction in general, but there are no local chapters of, say, ''Chocoholics Anonymous'' where I could stand and say that. Maybe there should be.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group that analyzed the paths taken by two favorites who came in second in the 1998 Summer Olympics found that the runners-up had covered more ground than the gold-medal winners, who had stayed closer to the inside of the track on curves, according to a report in The British Journal of Sports Medicine. The group, led by Dr. Andrew M. Jones of Manchester Metropolitan University, examined the 800-meter and 5,000-meter races in Sydney.
docs.abstract: Analysis by researchers at Manchester Metropolitan University, in report in British Journal of Sports Medicine, concludes that runners-up in 800-meter and 5,000-meter races at 1998 Summer Olympics, though swifter, covered more ground than gold-medal winners who stayed closer to inside of track on curves; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The widespread contamination of well water with arsenic in China and India has been linked to cancer and blackfoot disease, which brings on gangrene in the feet and legs. Now a new study from Taiwan points to another worry: drinking such water for two decades triples the risk of developing obstructions in the arteries leading to the brain, a danger sign for strokes and heart attacks.
docs.abstract: Study from Taiwan published in journal Circulation finds link between arterial brain obstructions, which could lead to strokes and heart attacks, and contamination of well water with arsenic in China and India; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The widespread contamination of well water with arsenic in China and India has been linked to cancer and blackfoot disease, which brings on gangrene in the feet and legs.    Now a new study from Taiwan points to another worry: drinking such water for...

docs.lead_paragraph: Men with low sperm counts have increased them significantly by taking combinations of zinc and folic acid, a new study conducted in the Netherlands has found. The study, published in the current issue of Fertility and Sterility, the journal of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, compared the effect of giving 103 patients either folic acid, zinc sulfate, both, or a placebo.
docs.abstract: Netherlands study, published in current issue of Fertility and Sterility, finds that men with low sperm counts have increased them significantly by taking combination of zinc and folic acid; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Maya child growing up in the United States is three times as likely to be overweight as the average American child, according to a new survey conducted by an anthropologist at the University of Michigan at Dearborn. Of about 300 Maya children ages 6 to 12 in Florida and California, 42 percent were overweight based on criteria used by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, compared with just under 15 percent of American children in the same age range, the anthropologist, Dr. Barry Bogin reported.

headline.main: Maya Children Face Serious Weight Problems

docs.abstract: University of Michigan anthropologist Barry Bogin, addressing American Assn for Advancement of Science symposium on obesity, says survey of 300 Maya children ages 6 to 12 in Florida and California has found that they are three times as likely to be overweight as average American child; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A Maya child growing up in the United States is three times as likely to be overweight as the average American child, according to a new survey conducted by an anthropologist at the University of Michigan at Dearborn.    Of about 300 Maya children...

docs.lead_paragraph: The obesity warnings are everywhere. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that with 35 percent of Americans overweight and 27 percent obese, obesity ''has risen at an epidemic rate during the past 20 years.'' In December, Dr. David Satcher, who was surgeon general, said obesity would soon succeed tobacco as the leading cause of preventable deaths in America.

headline.main: Asking if Obesity Is a Disease or Just a Symptom

docs.abstract: Article on debate among researchers over whether obesity, which some say is becoming epidemic in America, is symptom or disease; some suspect it is symptom and that losing weight does little or nothing for underlying illness; caution against belief that disease can increase chances of developing diabetes or heart disease or dying early; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The obesity warnings are everywhere. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that with 35 percent of Americans overweight and 27 percent obese, obesity ''has risen at an epidemic rate during the past 20 years.''     In December, Dr. David...

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's children -- indeed, the world's -- are fatter than ever, with no end in sight to their increasing girth, and unless something is done now to reverse this trend, the health costs, already very high, will be astronomical in the not-too-distant future. One-fourth of all school-age children are now overweight and one-eighth are obese, twice the proportions found just two decades ago.

headline.main: Fighting the Lessons Schools Teach on Fat

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on drastic changes that will be necessary to reverse trend toward obesity among America's children; notes restaurants offer ever-larger portions, schools, facing budget constraints, have been cancelling athletic programs and children lead more sedentary lives; notes children learn by example and child's tastebuds can be programmed, in a sense, to prefer healthier foods; views roles of parents and schools as essential; graph (M)
